subject: Re: [junit] Strange request: examples of "beautiful" test code
msgSnippet: Yes.  I don t like annotations.  I think they are a language kludge.  I expect a backlash at some point. Michael Feathers michaelfeathers.typepad.com
messageBody:
Yes. I don't like annotations. I think they are a language kludge. I
expect a backlash at some point.

Michael Feathers
michaelfeathers.typepad.com
www.objectmentor.com



Stephen Smith wrote:

>Cedric, I agree with Michael. The former example is a lot clearer and
>simpler to me, primarily for the reason that the structure of a
>try...catch block is so easy to understand. Even the most inexperienced
>Java developer can understand try...catch, whereas annotations can be a
>difficult subject to explain. Code to describe code? Using a
>JavaDoc-style syntax? Etc.
>
>I'd also suggest that the former example is more elegant, but we enter
>dangerously subjective territory at this point...
>--
>Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
>http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/
>
>Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
>
>>On 11/28/06, Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...
>><mailto:mfeathers%40mindspring.com>> wrote:
>> >
>> > I think that JUnit3 test code is more beautiful than its competitors and
>> > successors because it's appropriately minimal. It makes good things easy
>> > and bad things difficult.
>>
>>Seriously?
>>
>>You find this:
>>
>>public void testDivideByZero() {
>>try {
>>int n = 2 / 0;
>>fail();
>>}
>>catch(ArithmeticException ex) {
>>// pass
>>}
>>}
>>
>>easier to read than this:
>>
>>@Test(expected=ArithmeticException.class)
>>public void divideByZero() {
>>int n = 2 / 0;
>>}
>>
>>?
>>
>>--
>>Cédric
